questions.text: The spermatic cord contains structures running to and from the testis and suspends the testis in the scrotum. Which of the following statements regarding the spermatic cord is true?

choices.text: Internal spermatic fascia is derived from the transversalis fascia.
Cremasteric fascia is derived from the external oblique muscle.
External spermatic fascia is derived from scarpa fascia.
Colles fascia is derived from transversalis fascia.
Dartos fascia is derived from scarpa fascia.

questions.solution:
The spermatic cord contains structures running to and from the testis and suspends the testis in the scrotum. The spermatic cord begins at the deep inguinal ring lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels, passes through the inguinal canal, exits at the superficial inguinal ring, and ends in the scrotum at the posterior border of the testis. Fascial coverings derived from the anterolateral abdominal wall surround the spermatic cord during prenatal development.

The coverings of the spermatic cord from deep to superficial are the internal spermatic fascia (derived from the transversalis fascia), cremasteric fascia (derived from aponeurosis of the internal oblique muscle), and external spermatic fascia (derived from aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle).  



Option Analysis

✅ Internal spermatic fascia is derived from the transversalis fascia.   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cremasteric fascia is derived from the external oblique muscle.:
Incorrect: The cremasteric fascia is derived from the internal oblique muscle.  
❌ External spermatic fascia is derived from scarpa fascia.  :
Incorrect: The external spermatic fascia is derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle. In contrast, scarpa fascia is a membranous layer in the anterior abdominal wall.  
❌ Colles fascia is derived from transversalis fascia.  :
Incorrect: The colles fascia is not a part of the spermatic cord. In contrast, the three fascial layers that make up the spermatic cord are the internal spermatic, cremasteric, and external spermatic fascia.  
❌ Dartos fascia is derived from scarpa fascia.  :
Incorrect: The dartos fascia is a layer of connective tissue within the penis. The dartos fascia is not a part of the spermatic cord.

questions.text: During anatomy lab, a student is dissecting a cadaver and identifies the female internal reproductive organs and several surrounding ligaments. One of these ligaments is found to contain the ovarian vessels. Which of the following is true regarding this ligament?

choices.text: This ligament is the suspensory ligament.
This ligament is the ovarian ligament.
It is made of folds of peritoneum.
This ligament is the cardinal ligament.
This ligament connects the ovaries to the uterus.

questions.solution:
The female reproductive system is made up of internal and external organs. The internal organs are the ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix, and vagina. These organs are anchored in space by several ligaments.  

There are three ligaments attached to each ovary. The first one is the ovarian ligament, which connects the medial side of the ovaries to the uterus. The second is the suspensory ligament, which connects the ovaries to the lateral pelvic wall. The ovarian vessels (ovarian artery and vein) and the nerve plexus run in the suspensory ligament. Finally, the broad ligament, composed of peritoneal folds, also attaches to the ovaries (termed the mesovarium).



The uterus has four main ligaments. The first is the cardinal ligament, and it connects the uterus to the lateral pelvic walls and contains the uterine blood vessels. Then, there is the round ligament, which connects the uterus to the anterior abdominal wall. The uterosacral ligament extends superiorly and posteriorly from the side of the cervix to the middle of the sacrum. Finally, the uterus is also attached by the broad ligament.

 

Finally, the fallopian tubes are also anchored by the broad ligament (termed the mesosalpinx). 

Option Analysis

✅ This ligament is the suspensory ligament. :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  This ligament is the ovarian ligament.  :
Incorrect: The ovarian ligament connects the ovaries to the uterus. However, the ovarian vessels are found in the suspensory ligament, not the ovarian ligament.  
❌ It is made of folds of peritoneum. :
Incorrect: The broad ligament is made of folds of peritoneal tissue and is responsible for anchoring the ovaries in place. However, the ovarian vessels do not run in the broad ligament.  
❌ This ligament is the cardinal ligament. :
Incorrect: The cardinal ligament contains the uterine (not the ovarian vessels) vessels. The cardinal ligament connects the uterus (and the cervix) to the lateral pelvic walls.  
❌ This ligament connects the ovaries to the uterus. :
Incorrect: The ovarian ligament connects the ovaries to the uterus. However, the ovarian vessels run in the suspensory ligament, not the ovarian ligament.

questions.text: Which of the following abdominal muscles/ligaments extend to the groin to form the deep and superficial inguinal rings?

choices.text: Deep Inguinal RingSuperficial Inguinal RingInguinal ligament   Lacunar ligament
Deep Inguinal RingSuperficial Inguinal Ring   Internal oblique   Transversus abdominis muscles
Deep Inguinal RingSuperficial Inguinal RingTransversalis fascia   Conjoint tendon
Deep Inguinal Ring   Superficial Inguinal Ring   Transversalis fasciaExternal oblique aponeurosis
Deep Inguinal RingSuperficial Inguinal RingExternal oblique aponeurosisInternal oblique aponeurosis

questions.solution:
The muscles and fascial layers of the anterior abdominal wall continue inferiorly to form the inguinal ligament and parts of the inguinal canal.

The inguinal canal starts at the deep inguinal ring, which is an opening in the transversalis fascia. The deep inguinal ring is located at the midpoint of the inguinal ligament, just lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels. It ends at the superficial inguinal ring, an opening in the external oblique aponeurosis.

Structures passing through the inguinal canal enter through the deep inguinal ring except for the ilioinguinal nerve, which enters the canal distal to the ring. All structures then exit via the superficial inguinal ring.

The inguinal canal has four boundaries: the anterior and posterior walls, roof, and floor.  

  •  Roof (superior): internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles 
  •  Floor (inferior): inguinal ligament (shelving edge of external oblique) and lacunar ligament 
  •  Posterior wall: transversalis fascia laterally and conjoint tendon medially  
  •  Anterior wall: external oblique aponeurosis and internal oblique muscle  


Option Analysis

❌ Deep Inguinal RingSuperficial Inguinal RingInguinal ligament   Lacunar ligament  :
Incorrect: The inguinal and lacunar ligaments form the inguinal canal floor. In contrast, the deep inguinal ring is formed by the transversalis fascia, and the external oblique aponeurosis forms the superficial inguinal ring.   
❌ Deep Inguinal RingSuperficial Inguinal Ring   Internal oblique   Transversus abdominis muscles  :
Incorrect: The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles form the roof of the inguinal canal. In contrast, the deep inguinal ring is formed by the transversalis fascia, and the external oblique aponeurosis forms the superficial inguinal ring.   
❌ Deep Inguinal RingSuperficial Inguinal RingTransversalis fascia   Conjoint tendon:
Incorrect: The posterior wall of the inguinal canal is formed by the transversalis fascia laterally and conjoint tendon medially. While the deep inguinal ring is formed by the transversalis fascia, the superficial inguinal ring is formed by the external oblique aponeurosis.   
✅ Deep Inguinal Ring   Superficial Inguinal Ring   Transversalis fasciaExternal oblique aponeurosis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Deep Inguinal RingSuperficial Inguinal RingExternal oblique aponeurosisInternal oblique aponeurosis:
Incorrect: The anterior wall of the inguinal canal is made up of the external oblique and internal oblique aponeurosis. In contrast, the deep inguinal ring is formed by the transversalis fascia, and the external oblique aponeurosis forms the superficial inguinal ring.

questions.text: The pampiniform plexus is part of the thermoregulatory system of the testis. The veins of each  pampiniform plexus converge superiorly to form the testicular veins. Which of the following statements regarding the drainage of the testicular veins is most accurate?

choices.text: The right and left testicular vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava.
The right testicular vein drains directly into the right iliac vein.
The left testicular vein drains directly into the left renal vein.
The right testicular vein drains directly into the right renal vein.
The right and left testicular vein drains directly into the common iliac vein.

questions.solution:
The veins emerging from the testis and epididymis form the pampiniform venous plexus, a network of 8-12 veins that lies anterior to the ductus deferens and surround the testicular artery in the spermatic cord.

The pampiniform plexus is part of the thermoregulatory system of the testis (along with the cremaster and dartos muscles), helping to keep the organ at a constant temperature. The veins of each pampiniform plexus converge superiorly to form the testicular vein. The right testicular vein empties into the inferior vena cava (IVC), whereas the left testicular vein drains into the left renal vein, which then drains into the IVC.  



Option Analysis

❌ The right and left testicular vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava.  :
Incorrect: Only the right testicular vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava (IVC). The left testicular vein drains into the left renal vein, emptying into the IVC.  
❌ The right testicular vein drains directly into the right iliac vein.  :
Incorrect: The right testicular vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava (IVC), not the right iliac vein.  
✅ The left testicular vein drains directly into the left renal vein.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The right testicular vein drains directly into the right renal vein.  :
Incorrect: The right testicular vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava (IVC), not the right renal vein.  
❌ The right and left testicular vein drains directly into the common iliac vein.  :
Incorrect: The right testicular vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava (IVC). The left testicular vein drains into the left renal vein.

questions.text: A group of investigators are studying the cells of the seminiferous tubules of the testes. Which of the following best describes the function of the cell labeled 7 in the histological image below.

choices.text: Produce primary spermatocytes
Produce mullerian inhibiting factor
Regulates spermatogenesis
Secretes testosterone
Secretes androgen binding proteins

questions.solution:
The cells labeled 7 in the histological image shown above are Leydig cells in the seminiferous tubule. Leydig cells are large, round, or polygonal cells with round nuclei and often have an eosinophilic cytoplasm because of the lipid droplets that they typically contain. It secretes testosterone in the presence of the luteinizing hormone (LH).  

Other cells of the seminiferous tubule include spermatogonia (labeled 4) and Sertoli cells (labeled 5). The spermatogonia are the undifferentiated germ cells that are mainly found along the periphery of the germinal epithelium, against the basement membrane. They maintain the germ cell pool and produce primary spermatocytes. Sertoli cells, on the other hand, are large columnar cells with pale, euchromatic nuclei and prominent nucleoli. These cells provide nutrition and mechanical support for the spermatogenic cells. Sertoli cells also secrete two hormones - activin and inhibin - which provide positive and negative feedback to the pituitary gland for follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) secretion, respectively.   

Option Analysis

❌ Produce primary spermatocytes  :
Incorrect: Primary spermatocytes are produced by spermatogonia, which are labeled 4 in the figure.  
❌ Produce mullerian inhibiting factor  :
Incorrect: Mullerian inhibiting factor is produced by the Sertoli cells which are labeled 5 in the figure.  
❌ Regulates spermatogenesis  :
Incorrect: Sertoli cells in the seminiferous tubule regulate spermatogenesis, which is labeled 5 in the figure.  
✅ Secretes testosterone  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Secretes androgen binding proteins  :
Incorrect: Sertoli cells in the seminiferous tubule secrete androgen-binding proteins.

questions.text: A pathologist examines a segment of the testes to determine the cells' functions. One cell was identified lining the seminiferous tubules near the basolateral membrane. These cells secrete a hormone called inhibin that decreases the production of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the anterior pituitary. Which of the following is an additional function?

choices.text: Formation of the blood-testis-barrier
Production of testosterone
Feedback inhibition of luteinizing hormone (LH)
Production of primary spermatocyte
Maintenance of germ cell pool

questions.solution:
Sertoli cells are essential cells in the testes and have many functions. Sertoli cells are non-germ cells found in the testes' seminiferous tubules. These cells are mainly located on the basolateral side of the tubules.

First, during the intrauterine period, Sertoli cells secrete Mullerian inhibitory factor (MIF), which prevents the development of the female reproductive organs. Sertoli cells are also crucial in developing sperms by providing nutrients and regulating the environment in the seminiferous tubules. Additionally, Sertoli cells maintain a high amount of testosterone in the seminiferous tubules, which is needed to develop sperms. This is done by secreting androgen binding peptide (ABP), which captures the testosterone secreted by Leydig cells and allows more testosterone to enter the seminiferous tubules.

Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) stimulates the sertoli cells to secrete ABP. Sertoli cells regulate the secretion of FSH from the anterior pituitary by secreting a hormone called inhibin, which acts as a feedback inhibitor on FSH secretion. Finally, Sertoli cells protect the spermatozoa from autoimmune attacks. This is done by forming tight junctions between the Sertoli cells, creating the blood-testis barrier, which prevents the immune cells from attacking and surveilling the developing spermatozoa.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Formation of the blood-testis-barrier:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Production of testosterone:
Incorrect: Testosterone is produced by the Leydig cells, not Sertoli cells. Leydig cells are found in the interstitial space outside the seminiferous tubules.  
❌ Feedback inhibition of luteinizing hormone (LH)  :
Incorrect: Testosterone produced by Leydig cells is responsible for the feedback inhibition of LH, whereas Sertoli cells produce inhibin that is responsible for the feedback inhibition of FSH.  
❌ Production of primary spermatocyte:
Incorrect: Spermatogonia are the germ cells that produce primary spermatocytes, which then continue to develop into sperm. Sertoli cells are non-germ cells.  
❌ Maintenance of germ cell pool:
Incorrect: Spermatogonia are the germ cells that maintain the germ cell pool. Sertoli cells are non-germ cells.

questions.text: A pathologist evaluates the process of sperm production in the testes. It is noticed that cells at different levels of development are taken from the seminiferous tubules. Which of the following is true regarding spermatogenesis?

choices.text: Secondary spermatocytes undergo meiosis II to give rise to spermatids
Spermatogonia undergo meiosis I to give rise to primary spermatocyte
Primary spermatocytes have a haploid number of chromosomes (23 chromosomes)
Secondary spermatocytes have a haploid number of chromosomes (23 chromosomes) and one set of chromatids
Secondary spermatocytes undergo mitosis to give rise to spermatids

questions.solution:
Spermatogenesis is the process by which sperms are produced. It begins in puberty under the influence of the pulsatile secretions of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and luteinizing hormone (LH).

Spermatogenesis takes place in the seminiferous tubules and begins with spermatogonia. Each spermatogonium undergoes mitosis to give rise to two daughter cells, each having a diploid number of chromosomes (46 chromosomes). One daughter cell becomes a spermatogonium again, and the other daughter cell becomes a primary spermatocyte.

Primary spermatocytes begin moving towards the center of the seminiferous tubules and undergo meiosis one (meiosis I), giving rise to two daughter cells called secondary spermatocytes. Secondary spermatocytes have a haploid number of chromosomes (23 chromosomes) but two sets of chromatids.

Secondary spermatocytes then undergo meiosis 2 (meiosis II) to give rise to spermatids. Spermatids have a haploid number of chromosomes (23 chromosomes) but only one set of chromatids. Finally, the spermatids enter the lumen of the seminiferous tubules and undergo spermiogenesis, which involves structural changes of the spermatids (e.g., acquiring a tail and an acrosomal cap) to become sperm.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Secondary spermatocytes undergo meiosis II to give rise to spermatids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Spermatogonia undergo meiosis I to give rise to primary spermatocyte:
Incorrect: Spermatogonia undergoes mitosis (not meiosis) and gives rise to two daughter cells, each of which has 46 chromosomes. One of the daughter cells becomes a primary spermatocyte.  
❌ Primary spermatocytes have a haploid number of chromosomes (23 chromosomes):
Incorrect: Primary spermatocytes have a diploid number of chromosomes (46 chromosomes).  
❌ Secondary spermatocytes have a haploid number of chromosomes (23 chromosomes) and one set of chromatids:
Incorrect: Secondary spermatocytes have a haploid number of chromosomes (23 chromosomes) and two sets of chromatids. They undergo meiosis II to give rise to spermatids with a haploid number of chromosomes (23 chromosomes) and one set of chromatids.  
❌ Secondary spermatocytes undergo mitosis to give rise to spermatids:
Incorrect: Secondary spermatocytes undergo meiosis II (not mitosis) to give rise to spermatids.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation. During evaluation of sexual development of the boy, his genitalia and pubic hair are at Tanner stage 2 of sexual development. Which of the following characteristics are expected to be seen at this stage of sexual development?

choices.text: Testicular enlargement
The penis enlarges in size and length
The penis enlarges in width
Coarse pubic hair appears but does not extend to the thighs
Coarse pubic hair appears and extends to the inner thighs

questions.solution:
Tanner scale is a scale used to evaluate the development of primary and secondary sexual characteristics in both males and females, and it represents a set of steps that males and females go through at puberty. The tanner scale assesses three independent criteria: the genitalia, pubic hair, and breast development in females. There are five stages in the tanner scale which are:

  • Stage 1: the prepubertal stage; no pubic hair is present in either males or females; males have a small penis and testis; females have a flat chest.  
  • Stage 2: soft pubic hair starts to appear in males and females; the testes start to enlarge in males; breast buds appear in females.  
  • Stage 3: pubic hair begins coarsening; the penis starts to enlarge in both size and length; in females, the breast mounds form and the breasts enlarge.  
  • Stage 4: pubic hair covers the pubic area; the penis widens; the breasts continue to enlarge and form a mound on mound contour.  
  • Stage 5: pubic hair extends to the inner thighs; the penis and testes reach adult size; the breasts reach adult contour. 
 


Option Analysis

✅ Testicular enlargement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The penis enlarges in size and length:
Incorrect: Enlargement of penile size and length happens during Tanner stage 3 of development.  
❌ The penis enlarges in width:
Incorrect: The penis enlarges in width at Tanner stage 4 of development.  
❌ Coarse pubic hair appears but does not extend to the thighs:
Incorrect: Coarsening of the pubic hair begins in Tanner stage 3 and continues in Tanner stage 4 to cover the pubic area but without extending to the inner thighs. In Tanner stage 2, soft pubic hair starts to appear.  
❌ Coarse pubic hair appears and extends to the inner thighs:
Incorrect: In Tanner stage 5 pubic hair extends into the inner thighs.

questions.text: A researcher studies the development of the male genitalia in utero. Which of the following hormones is directly responsible for the differentiation of the epididymis during the intrauterine period?

choices.text: Androstenedione
Testosterone
Dihydrotestosterone
Gonadotropin-releasing hormone
Luteinizing hormone

questions.solution:
Testosterone is the primary male hormone and is an androgen. The effects of testosterone are first seen in the fetus. During the first six weeks of development, the reproductive tissues of males and females are identical. Still, in week seven, genes in the sex-determining region of the Y chromosome (called the SRY gene) initiate the development of testicles.  

Once they form, the fetal testicles secrete testosterone which guides the development of the male urogenital tract and external genitalia, as well as testicular descent through the inguinal canal, which happens in the last two months of fetal development. The functions of testosterone are summarized in the table below.  

Testosterone is converted to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) by 5α-reductase. DHT is responsible for the early differentiation of the penis, scrotum, and prostate. It is also involved in the late phase of prostate growth, balding, and sebaceous gland activity.  



Option Analysis

❌ Androstenedione:
Incorrect: Androstenedione is released from the adrenal glands. It is the least potent androgen and does not directly affect the differentiation of the epididymis.  
✅ Testosterone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dihydrotestosterone:
Incorrect: Dihydrotestosterone (DHT) is responsible for the early differentiation of the penis, scrotum, and prostate. It is also involved in the late phase of prostate growth, balding, and sebaceous gland activity.  
❌ Gonadotropin-releasing hormone  :
Incorrect: Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) stimulates the release of luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) in the pituitary which in turn stimulates the release of testosterone.  
❌ Luteinizing hormone:
Incorrect: Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) stimulates the release of luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) in the pituitary, which in turn stimulates the release of testosterone.
